standard_metadata.standard_description: Interpret and compute quotients of fractions, and solve word problems involving division of fractions by fractions, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem.

question.content: Keala is making a new book cover before giving their favorite picture book to their little brother. The cover is $22\dfrac{1}{4}\,\text{cm}$ tall. It has a rectangular shape and an area of $890\,\text{cm}^2$.  **How wide across is Keala's book cover?**   $\text{cm}$

hints.content: ###Modeling the situation  $\maroonE{(\text{side 1})}\times \blueE{(\text{side 2)}} = \purpleD{(\text{cover area})}$  We don't know the width of the second side. Let's rewrite the multiplication equation as an equivalent division equation. Then we can fill in the values we know and divide.

###Writing a division equation  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{side 2})} &= \purpleD{(\text{cover area})} \div \maroonE{\text{(side 1)}} \\\\ &= \purpleD{890} \div \maroonE{22\dfrac{1}{4}} \end{align}$  It will be easier to divide if we rewrite the mixed number as a fraction greater than $1$. [[☃ explanation 1]]  $\blueE{(\text{side 2})} = \purpleD{890} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{89}{4}}$

###Rewriting with the reciprocal  Dividing by $\maroonE{\dfrac{89}{4}}$ is equivalent to multiplying by its reciprocal.    The reciprocal of $\maroonE{\dfrac{89}{4}}$ is $\goldE{\dfrac{4}{89}}$.  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{side 2})} &= \purpleD{890} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{89}{4}}\\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac{890}{1}} \times \goldE{\dfrac{4}{89}}\\\\ &= \blueE{\dfrac{\cancel{89} \times 10 \times 4}{\cancel{89}}}\\\\ &= \blueE{40} \end{align}$
Keala's book cover is $\blueE{40\,\text{cm}}$ across.

question.content: Gabriel is designing a rectangular planter box for their garden. It needs to cover an area of $15\dfrac12\,\text{m}^2$. Gabriel wants it to be $7\dfrac{3}{4}\,\text{m}$ long.  **How wide does the planter box need to be?**   $\text{m}$

hints.content: ###Modeling the situation  $\maroonE{(\text{side 1})}\times \blueE{(\text{side 2)}} = \purpleD{(\text{planter area})}$  We don't know the width of the second side. Let's rewrite the multiplication equation as an equivalent division equation. Then we can fill in the values we know and divide.

###Writing a division equation  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{side 2})} &= \purpleD{(\text{planter area})} \div \maroonE{\text{(side 1)}} \\\\ &= \purpleD{15\dfrac12} \div \maroonE{7\dfrac{3}{4}} \end{align}$  It will be easier to divide if we rewrite the mixed numbers as fractions greater than $1$. [[☃ explanation 1]]  $\blueE{(\text{side 2})} = \purpleD{\dfrac{31}{2}} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{31}{4}}$

###Rewriting with the reciprocal  Dividing by $\maroonE{\dfrac{31}{4}}$ is equivalent to multiplying by its reciprocal.    The reciprocal of $\maroonE{\dfrac{31}{4}}$ is $\goldE{\dfrac{4}{31}}$.  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{side 2})} &= \purpleD{\dfrac{31}{2}} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{31}{4}}\\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac{\cancel{31}}{2}} \times \goldE{\dfrac{4}{\cancel{31}}}\\\\ &= \blueE{\dfrac{4}{2}}\\\\ &= \blueE{2} \end{align}$
The planter box needs to be $\blueE{2\,\text{m}}$ wide.

question.content: Marco's class is painting a  on the side of their school. The mural covers a $3\dfrac{1}{2}\,\text{m}$ high, rectangular wall. It has an area of $28\,\text{m}^2$.  **What is the length of the mural?**   $\text{m}$

hints.content: ###Modeling the situation  $\maroonE{(\text{side 1})}\times \blueE{(\text{side 2)}} = \purpleD{(\text{mural area})}$  We don't know the length of the second side. Let's rewrite the multiplication equation as an equivalent division equation. Then we can fill in the values we know and divide.

###Writing a division equation  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{side 2})} &= \purpleD{(\text{mural area})} \div \maroonE{\text{(side 1)}} \\\\ &= \purpleD{28} \div \maroonE{3\dfrac{1}{2}} \end{align}$  It will be easier to divide if we rewrite the mixed number as a fraction greater than $1$. [[☃ explanation 1]]  $\blueE{(\text{side 2})} = \purpleD{28} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{7}{2}}$

###Rewriting with the reciprocal  Dividing by $\maroonE{\dfrac{7}{2}}$ is equivalent to multiplying by its reciprocal.    The reciprocal of $\maroonE{\dfrac{7}{2}}$ is $\goldE{\dfrac{2}{7}}$.  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{side 2})} &= \purpleD{28} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{7}{2}}\\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac{28}{1}} \times \goldE{\dfrac{2}{7}}\\\\ &= \blueE{\dfrac{\cancel{7} \times 4 \times 2}{\cancel{7}}}\\\\ &= \blueE{8} \end{align}$
The mural is $\blueE{8\,\text{m}}$ long.

question.content: An electrician plans to install solar panels on a rectangular section of roof with an area of $180\,\text{m}^2$. This width of this section of roof is $7\dfrac15\,\text{m}$ across.  **What is the length of this section of roof?**   $\text{m}$

hints.content: ###Modeling the situation  $\maroonE{(\text{side 1})}\times \blueE{(\text{side 2)}} = \purpleD{(\text{roof area})}$  We don't know the length of the second side. Let's rewrite the multiplication equation as an equivalent division equation. Then we can fill in the values we know and divide.

###Writing a division equation  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{side 2})} &= \purpleD{(\text{roof area})} \div \maroonE{\text{(side 1)}} \\\\ &= \purpleD{180} \div \maroonE{7\dfrac{1}{5}} \end{align}$  It will be easier to divide if we rewrite the mixed number as a fraction greater than $1$. [[☃ explanation 1]]  $\blueE{(\text{side 2})} = \purpleD{180} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{36}{5}}$

###Rewriting with the reciprocal  Dividing by $\maroonE{\dfrac{36}{5}}$ is equivalent to multiplying by its reciprocal.    The reciprocal of $\maroonE{\dfrac{36}{5}}$ is $\goldE{\dfrac{5}{36}}$.  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{side 2})} &= \purpleD{180} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{36}{5}}\\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac{180}{1}} \times \goldE{\dfrac{5}{36}}\\\\ &= \blueE{\dfrac{\cancel{18} \times 10 \times 5}{\cancel{18} \times 2}}\\\\ &= \blueE{\dfrac{50}{2}}\\\\ &= \blueE{25} \end{align}$
The length of this section of roof is $\blueE{25\,\text{m}}$.

question.content: Claire is making a frame to display a drawing she made. The frame is $11\dfrac{1}{5}\,\text{cm}$ wide. The frame has a rectangular shape and an area of $560\,\text{cm}^2$.   **How tall is the frame?**   $\text{cm}$

hints.content: ###Modeling the situation  $\maroonE{(\text{side 1})}\times \blueE{(\text{side 2)}} = \purpleD{(\text{frame area})}$  We don't know the height of the second side. Let's rewrite the multiplication equation as an equivalent division equation. Then we can fill in the values we know and divide.

###Writing a division equation  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{side 2})} &= \purpleD{(\text{frame area})} \div \maroonE{\text{(side 1)}} \\\\ &= \purpleD{560} \div \maroonE{11\dfrac{1}{5}} \end{align}$  It will be easier to divide if we rewrite the mixed number as a fraction greater than $1$. [[☃ explanation 1]]  $\blueE{(\text{side 2})} = \purpleD{560} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{56}{5}}$

###Rewriting with the reciprocal  Dividing by $\maroonE{\dfrac{56}{5}}$ is equivalent to multiplying by its reciprocal.    The reciprocal of $\maroonE{\dfrac{56}{5}}$ is $\goldE{\dfrac{5}{56}}$.  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{side 2})} &= \purpleD{560} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{56}{5}}\\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac{560}{1}} \times \goldE{\dfrac{5}{56}}\\\\ &= \blueE{\dfrac{\cancel{56} \times 10 \times 5}{\cancel{56}}}\\\\ &= \blueE{50} \end{align}$
The frame is $\blueE{50\,\text{cm}}$ tall.

question.content: Japhet is making small rectangular tiles for a . Each tile has an area of $7\,\text{cm}^2$ and is $1\dfrac14\,\text{cm}$ wide.  **How long is each tile?**   $\text{cm}$

hints.content: ###Modeling the situation  $\maroonE{(\text{side 1})}\times \blueE{(\text{side 2)}} = \purpleD{(\text{tile area})}$  We don't know the length of the second side. Let's rewrite the multiplication equation as an equivalent division equation. Then we can fill in the values we know and divide.

###Writing a division equation  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{side 2})} &= \purpleD{(\text{tile area})} \div \maroonE{\text{(side 1)}} \\\\ &= \purpleD{7} \div \maroonE{1\dfrac{1}{4}} \end{align}$  It will be easier to divide if we rewrite the mixed number as a fraction greater than $1$. [[☃ explanation 1]]  $\blueE{(\text{side 2})} = \purpleD{7} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{5}{4}}$

###Rewriting with the reciprocal  Dividing by $\maroonE{\dfrac{5}{4}}$ is equivalent to multiplying by its reciprocal.    The reciprocal of $\maroonE{\dfrac{5}{4}}$ is $\goldE{\dfrac{4}{5}}$.  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{side 2})} &= \purpleD{7} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{5}{4}}\\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac{7}{1}} \times \goldE{\dfrac{4}{5}}\\\\ &= \blueE{\dfrac{28}{5}} \end{align}$
Each tile is $\blueE{5\dfrac35\,\text{cm}}$ long.

question.content: Katya is making a rectangular table that is $\dfrac34\,\text{m}$ wide. The table has an area of $1\dfrac15\,\text{m}^2$  **How long is the table?**   $\text{m}$

hints.content: ###Modeling the situation  $\maroonE{(\text{side 1})}\times \blueE{(\text{side 2)}} = \purpleD{(\text{table area})}$  We don't know the length of the second side. Let's rewrite the multiplication equation as an equivalent division equation. Then we can fill in the values we know and divide.

###Writing a division equation  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{side 2})} &= \purpleD{(\text{table area})} \div \maroonE{\text{(side 1)}} \\\\ &= \purpleD{1\dfrac15} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{3}{4}} \end{align}$  It will be easier to divide if we rewrite the mixed number as a fraction greater than $1$. [[☃ explanation 1]]  $\blueE{(\text{side 2})} = \purpleD{\dfrac{6}{5}} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{3}{4}}$

###Rewriting with the reciprocal  Dividing by $\maroonE{\dfrac{3}{4}}$ is equivalent to multiplying by its reciprocal.    The reciprocal of $\maroonE{\dfrac{3}{4}}$ is $\goldE{\dfrac{4}{3}}$.  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{side 2})} &= \purpleD{\dfrac{3}{4}} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{5}{4}}\\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac{6}{5}} \times \goldE{\dfrac{4}{3}}\\\\ &= \blueE{\dfrac{2 \times \cancel{3} \times 4}{5 \times \cancel{3}}}\\\\ &= \blueE{\dfrac{8}{5}} \end{align}$
The table is $\blueE{\dfrac85\,\text{m}}$ long.

question.content: Morgan is designing a rectangular quilt. The quilt will be $1\dfrac35\,\text{m}$ wide and will have an area of $6\,\text{m}^2$.  **How long is the quilt?**   $\text{m}$

hints.content: ###Modeling the situation  $\maroonE{(\text{side 1})}\times \blueE{(\text{side 2)}} = \purpleD{(\text{quilt area})}$  We don't know the length of the second side. Let's rewrite the multiplication equation as an equivalent division equation. Then we can fill in the values we know and divide.

###Writing a division equation  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{side 2})} &= \purpleD{(\text{quilt area})} \div \maroonE{\text{(side 1)}} \\\\ &= \purpleD{6} \div \maroonE{1\dfrac{3}{5}} \end{align}$  It will be easier to divide if we rewrite the mixed number as a fraction greater than $1$. [[☃ explanation 1]]  $\blueE{(\text{side 2})} = \purpleD{6} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{8}{5}}$

###Rewriting with the reciprocal  Dividing by $\maroonE{\dfrac{8}{5}}$ is equivalent to multiplying by its reciprocal.    The reciprocal of $\maroonE{\dfrac{8}{5}}$ is $\goldE{\dfrac{5}{8}}$.  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{side 2})} &= \purpleD{6} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{8}{5}}\\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac{6}{1}} \times \goldE{\dfrac{5}{8}}\\\\ &= \blueE{\dfrac{\cancel{2} \times 3 \times 5}{ \cancel{2} \times 4}}\\\\ &= \blueE{\dfrac{15}{4}} \end{align}$
The quilt is $\blueE{3\dfrac34\,\text{m}}$ long.

question.content: Avery is designing a large rectangular sign. They want the sign to have an area of $2\,\text{m}^2$ and a width of $\dfrac45\,\text{m}$.  **How tall should the sign be?**   $\text{m}$

hints.content: ###Modeling the situation  $\maroonE{(\text{side 1})}\times \blueE{(\text{side 2)}} = \purpleD{(\text{sign area})}$  We don't know the height of the second side. Let's rewrite the multiplication equation as an equivalent division equation. Then we can fill in the values we know and divide.
###Writing a division equation  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{side 2})} &= \purpleD{(\text{sign area})} \div \maroonE{\text{(side 1)}} \\\\ &= \purpleD{2} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{4}{5}} \end{align}$

###Rewriting with the reciprocal  Dividing by $\maroonE{\dfrac{4}{5}}$ is equivalent to multiplying by its reciprocal.    The reciprocal of $\maroonE{\dfrac{4}{5}}$ is $\goldE{\dfrac{5}{4}}$.  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{side 2})} &= \purpleD{2} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{4}{5}}\\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac{2}{1}} \times \goldE{\dfrac{5}{4}}\\\\ &= \blueE{\dfrac{\cancel{2} \times 5}{ \cancel{2} \times 2}}\\\\ &= \blueE{\dfrac{5}{2}} \end{align}$
The sign should be $\blueE{\dfrac52\,\text{m}}$ tall.

question.content: Nisha likes to make small rectangular paintings of cats. One of her paintings has an area of $33\,\text{cm}^2$ and a width of $7\dfrac12\,\text{cm}$.  **What is the height of this painting?**   $\text{cm}$

hints.content: ###Modeling the situation  $\maroonE{(\text{side 1})}\times \blueE{(\text{side 2)}} = \purpleD{(\text{painting area})}$  We don't know the height of the second side. Let's rewrite the multiplication equation as an equivalent division equation. Then we can fill in the values we know and divide.

###Writing a division equation  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{side 2})} &= \purpleD{(\text{painting area})} \div \maroonE{\text{(side 1)}} \\\\ &= \purpleD{33} \div \maroonE{7\dfrac{1}{2}} \end{align}$  It will be easier to divide if we rewrite the mixed number as a fraction greater than $1$. [[☃ explanation 1]]  $\blueE{(\text{side 2})} = \purpleD{33} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{15}{2}}$

###Rewriting with the reciprocal  Dividing by $\maroonE{\dfrac{15}{2}}$ is equivalent to multiplying by its reciprocal.    The reciprocal of $\maroonE{\dfrac{15}{2}}$ is $\goldE{\dfrac{2}{15}}$.  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{side 2})} &= \purpleD{33} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{15}{2}}\\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac{33}{1}} \times \goldE{\dfrac{2}{15}}\\\\ &= \blueE{\dfrac{\cancel{3} \times 11 \times 2}{ \cancel{3} \times 5}}\\\\ &= \blueE{\dfrac{22}{5}} \end{align}$
The height of this painting is $\blueE{4\dfrac25\,\text{cm}}$.

question.content: Carlos has $\dfrac45$ of a tank of fuel in his car. He uses $\dfrac{1}{10}$ of a tank per day.  **How many days will his fuel last?**   days

hints.content: ###Modeling the situation  $\blueE{(\text{fuel per day})}\times \maroonE{\text{days}} = \purpleD{(\text{total fuel})}$  We don't know the number of days. Let's rewrite the multiplication equation as an equivalent division equation. Then we can fill in the values we know and divide.

###Writing a division equation  $\begin{align} \maroonE{\text{days}} &= \purpleD{(\text{total fuel})} \div \blueE{\text{(fuel per day)}} \\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac{4}{5}} \div \blueE{\dfrac{1}{10}} \end{align}$

###Rewriting with the reciprocal  Dividing by $\blueE{\dfrac{1}{10}}$ is equivalent to multiplying by its reciprocal.  The reciprocal of $\blueE{\dfrac{1}{10}}$ is $\goldE{\dfrac{10}{1}}$.  $\begin{align} \maroonE{\text{days}} &= \purpleD{\dfrac{4}{5}} \div \blueE{\dfrac{1}{10}} \\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac{4}{5}} \times \goldE{\dfrac{10}{1}}\\\\ &= \maroonE{\dfrac{40}{5}}\\\\ &= \maroonE{8} \end{align}$
Carlos' fuel will last $\maroonE{8}$ days.

question.content: A piano teacher gives lessons that each last $1\dfrac12$ hours. Last week, they spent $22\dfrac12$ hours giving lessons.  **How many lessons did they give?**   lessons

hints.content: ###Modeling the situation  $\blueE{(\text{hours per lesson})}\times \maroonE{\text{lessons}} = \purpleD{(\text{total hours})}$  We don't know the number of lessons. Let's rewrite the multiplication equation as an equivalent division equation. Then we can fill in the values we know and divide.

###Writing a division equation  $\begin{align} \maroonE{\text{lessons}} &= \purpleD{(\text{total hours})} \div \blueE{\text{(hours per lesson)}} \\\\ &= \purpleD{22\dfrac{1}{2}} \div \blueE{1\dfrac{1}{2}} \end{align}$  It will be easier to divide if we rewrite the mixed numbers as fractions greater than $1$. [[☃ explanation 1]]  $\maroonE{\text{lessons}} = \purpleD{\dfrac{45}{2}} \div \blueE{\dfrac{3}{2}} $

###Rewriting with the reciprocal  Dividing by $\blueE{\dfrac{3}{2}}$ is equivalent to multiplying by its reciprocal.  The reciprocal of $\blueE{\dfrac{3}{2}}$ is $\goldE{\dfrac{2}{3}}$.  $\begin{align} \maroonE{\text{lessons}} &= \purpleD{\dfrac{45}{2}} \div \blueE{\dfrac{3}{2}} \\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac{45}{\cancel{2}}} \times \goldE{\dfrac{\cancel{2}}{3}}\\\\ &= \maroonE{\dfrac{45}{3}}\\\\ &= \maroonE{15} \end{align}$
The teacher gave $\maroonE{15}$ lessons.

question.content: Skylar is a lifeguard at a swimming pool. Last week, they worked $3\dfrac34$ equal-length shifts, because rain closed the pool early one day. Those shifts totaled $11\dfrac14$ hours of work.  **How long is a single shift?**   hours

hints.content: ###Modeling the situation  $\blueE{(\text{hours per shift})}\times \maroonE{\text{shifts}} = \purpleD{(\text{total hours})}$  We don't know the number of hours per shift. Let's rewrite the multiplication equation as an equivalent division equation. Then we can fill in the values we know and divide.

###Writing a division equation  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{hours per shift})} &= \purpleD{(\text{total hours})} \div \maroonE{\text{shifts}} \\\\ &= \purpleD{11\dfrac{1}{4}} \div \maroonE{3\dfrac{3}{4}} \end{align}$  It will be easier to divide if we rewrite the mixed numbers as fractions greater than $1$. [[☃ explanation 1]]  $\blueE{(\text{hours per shift})} = \purpleD{\dfrac{45}{4}} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{15}{4}} $

###Rewriting with the reciprocal  Dividing by $\maroonE{\dfrac{15}{4}}$ is equivalent to multiplying by its reciprocal.  The reciprocal of $\maroonE{\dfrac{15}{4}}$ is $\goldE{\dfrac{4}{15}}$.  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{hours per shift})} &= \purpleD{\dfrac{45}{4}} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{15}{4}} \\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac{45}{\cancel{4}}} \times \goldE{\dfrac{\cancel{4}}{15}}\\\\ &= \blueE{\dfrac{45}{15}}\\\\ &= \blueE{3} \end{align}$
Each shift is $\blueE{3}$ hours long.

question.content: Noam had a length of $13\dfrac{1}{3}\,\text{cm}$ of ribbon and cut $3\dfrac{1}{3}$ equal-sized strips the full width of the ribbon.  **How long is each whole strip?**   $\text{cm}$

hints.content: ###Modeling the situation  $\blueE{(\text{length per strip})}\times \maroonE{\text{strips}} = \purpleD{(\text{total length})}$  We don't know the length per strip. Let's rewrite the multiplication equation as an equivalent division equation. Then we can fill in the values we know and divide.

###Writing a division equation  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{length per strip})} &= \purpleD{(\text{total length})} \div \maroonE{\text{strips}} \\\\ &= \purpleD{13\dfrac{1}{3}} \div \maroonE{3\dfrac{1}{3}} \end{align}$  It will be easier to divide if we rewrite the mixed numbers as fractions greater than $1$. [[☃ explanation 1]]  $\blueE{(\text{length per strip})} = \purpleD{\dfrac{40}{3}} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{10}{3}} $

###Rewriting with the reciprocal  Dividing by $\maroonE{\dfrac{10}{3}}$ is equivalent to multiplying by its reciprocal.  The reciprocal of $\maroonE{\dfrac{10}{3}}$ is $\goldE{\dfrac{3}{10}}$.  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{length per strip})} &= \purpleD{\dfrac{40}{3}} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{10}{3}} \\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac{40}{\cancel{3}}} \times \goldE{\dfrac{\cancel{3}}{10}}\\\\ &= \blueE{\dfrac{40}{10}}\\\\ &= \blueE{4} \end{align}$
Each strip is $\blueE{4}\,\text{cm}$ long.

question.content: Tomas was able to fill $6\dfrac23$ equal-sized buckets with a total of $33\dfrac13$ liters of paint.  **How much paint was in each whole bucket?**   liters

hints.content: ###Modeling the situation  $\blueE{(\text{amount per bucket})}\times \maroonE{\text{buckets}} = \purpleD{(\text{total amount})}$  We don't know the amount per bucket. Let's rewrite the multiplication equation as an equivalent division equation. Then we can fill in the values we know and divide.

###Writing a division equation  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{amount per bucket})} &= \purpleD{(\text{total amount})} \div \maroonE{\text{buckets}} \\\\ &= \purpleD{33\dfrac{1}{3}} \div \maroonE{6\dfrac{2}{3}} \end{align}$  It will be easier to divide if we rewrite the mixed numbers as fractions greater than $1$. [[☃ explanation 1]]  $\blueE{(\text{amount per bucket})} = \purpleD{\dfrac{100}{3}} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{20}{3}} $

###Rewriting with the reciprocal  Dividing by $\maroonE{\dfrac{20}{3}}$ is equivalent to multiplying by its reciprocal.  The reciprocal of $\maroonE{\dfrac{20}{3}}$ is $\goldE{\dfrac{3}{20}}$.  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{amount per bucket})} &= \purpleD{\dfrac{100}{3}} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{20}{3}} \\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac{100}{\cancel{3}}} \times \goldE{\dfrac{\cancel{3}}{20}}\\\\ &= \blueE{\dfrac{100}{20}}\\\\ &= \blueE{5} \end{align}$
Each whole bucket held $\blueE{5}$ liters of paint.

question.content: Amira had $\dfrac{3}{4}$ of a bag of cat food. The food lasted $7\dfrac{1}{2}$ weeks.  **How much cat food did Amira's cats eat per week?**   bags

hints.content: ###Modeling the situation  $\blueE{(\text{bags per week})}\times \maroonE{\text{weeks}} = \purpleD{(\text{total bags})}$  We don't know the number of bags per week. Let's rewrite the multiplication equation as an equivalent division equation. Then we can fill in the values we know and divide.

###Writing a division equation  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{bags per week})} &= \purpleD{(\text{total bags})} \div \maroonE{\text{weeks}} \\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac{3}{4}} \div \maroonE{7\dfrac{1}{2}} \end{align}$  It will be easier to divide if we rewrite the mixed number as a fraction greater than $1$. [[☃ explanation 1]]  $\blueE{(\text{bags per week})} = \purpleD{\dfrac{3}{4}} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{15}{2}} $

###Rewriting with the reciprocal  Dividing by $\maroonE{\dfrac{15}{2}}$ is equivalent to multiplying by its reciprocal.  The reciprocal of $\maroonE{\dfrac{15}{2}}$ is $\goldE{\dfrac{2}{15}}$.  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{bags per week})} &= \purpleD{\dfrac{3}{4}} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{15}{2}}\\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac{3}{4}} \times \goldE{\dfrac{2}{15}}\\\\ &= \blueE{\dfrac{6}{60}}\\\\ &= \blueE{\dfrac{1}{10}} \end{align}$
It makes sense to be able to eat a fraction of a bag per week, so Amira's cats ate $\blueE{\dfrac{1}{10}}$ of a bag of food per week.

question.content: Lian's dog eats $\dfrac{1}{20}$ of a bag of dog food each week. Lian currently has $\dfrac{5}{8}$ of a bag remaining.  **How many weeks will it take Lian's dog to finish this remaining food?**   weeks

hints.content: ###Modeling the situation  $\blueE{(\text{bags per week})}\times \maroonE{\text{weeks}} = \purpleD{(\text{total bags})}$  We don't know the number of weeks. Let's rewrite the multiplication equation as an equivalent division equation. Then we can fill in the values we know and divide.

###Writing a division equation  $\begin{align} \maroonE{\text{weeks}} &= \purpleD{(\text{total bags})} \div \blueE{(\text{bags per week})} \\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac{5}{8}} \div \blueE{\dfrac{1}{20}} \end{align}$

###Rewriting with the reciprocal  Dividing by $\blueE{\dfrac{1}{20}}$ is equivalent to multiplying by its reciprocal.  The reciprocal of $\blueE{\dfrac{1}{20}}$ is $\goldE{\dfrac{20}{1}}$.  $\begin{align} \maroonE{\text{weeks}} &= \purpleD{\dfrac{5}{8}} \div \blueE{\dfrac{1}{20}}\\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac{5}{8}} \times \goldE{\dfrac{20}{1}}\\\\ &= \maroonE{\dfrac{100}{8}}\\\\ &= \maroonE{\dfrac{25}{2}} \end{align}$
It makes sense for a bag to last for a fraction of a week, so it will take Lian's dog $\maroonE{12\dfrac12}$ weeks to finish the remaining food.

question.content: Paolo helped in the community garden for $2\dfrac{3}{4}$ hours this week. That was $1\dfrac{5}{6}$ equal-length shifts, because Paolo stopped early one day when it started to rain.  **How long is a single shift?**   hours

hints.content: ###Modeling the situation  $\blueE{(\text{hours per shift})}\times \maroonE{\text{shifts}} = \purpleD{(\text{total hours})}$  We don't know the number of hours per shift. Let's rewrite the multiplication equation as an equivalent division equation. Then we can fill in the values we know and divide.

###Writing a division equation  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{hours per shift})} &= \purpleD{(\text{total hours})} \div \maroonE{\text{shifts}} \\\\ &= \purpleD{2\dfrac{3}{4}} \div \maroonE{1\dfrac{5}{6}} \end{align}$  It will be easier to divide if we rewrite the mixed numbers as fractions greater than $1$. [[☃ explanation 1]]  $\blueE{(\text{hours per shift})} = \purpleD{\dfrac{11}{4}} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{11}{6}} $

###Rewriting with the reciprocal  Dividing by $\maroonE{\dfrac{11}{6}}$ is equivalent to multiplying by its reciprocal.  The reciprocal of $\maroonE{\dfrac{11}{6}}$ is $\goldE{\dfrac{6}{11}}$.  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{hours per shift})} &= \purpleD{\dfrac{11}{4}} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{11}{6}} \\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac{\cancel{11}}{4}} \times \goldE{\dfrac{6}{\cancel{11}}}\\\\ &= \blueE{\dfrac{6}{4}}\\\\ &= \blueE{\dfrac{3}{2}} \end{align}$
It makes sense to have a fraction of an hour in each shift, so each shift is $\blueE{\dfrac{3}{2}}$ hours long.

question.content: A $13\,\text{km}$ stretch of road needs repairs. Workers can repair $3\dfrac12\,\text{km}$ of road per week.  **How many weeks will it take to repair this stretch of road?**   weeks

hints.content: ###Modeling the situation  $\blueE{(\text{km per week})}\times \maroonE{\text{weeks}} = \purpleD{(\text{total km})}$  We don't know the number of weeks. Let's rewrite the multiplication equation as an equivalent division equation. Then we can fill in the values we know and divide.

###Writing a division equation  $\begin{align} \maroonE{\text{weeks}} &= \purpleD{(\text{total km})} \div \blueE{(\text{km per week})} \\\\ &= \purpleD{13} \div \blueE{3\dfrac{1}{2}} \end{align}$  It will be easier to divide if we rewrite the mixed number as a fraction greater than $1$. [[☃ explanation 1]]  $\maroonE{\text{weeks}} = \purpleD{13} \div \blueE{\dfrac{7}{2}} $

###Rewriting with the reciprocal  Dividing by $\blueE{\dfrac{7}{2}}$ is equivalent to multiplying by its reciprocal.  The reciprocal of $\blueE{\dfrac{7}{2}}$ is $\goldE{\dfrac{2}{7}}$.  $\begin{align} \maroonE{\text{weeks}} &= \purpleD{13} \div \blueE{\dfrac{7}{2}}\\\\ &= \purpleD{13} \times \goldE{\dfrac{2}{7}}\\\\ &= \maroonE{\dfrac{26}{7}} \end{align}$
It makes sense for the work to take a fraction of a week, so it will take $\maroonE{3\dfrac57}$ weeks to repair this stretch of road.

question.content: Ana drinks  out of glasses that each hold $\dfrac18$ of a liter. She has $\dfrac{7}{10}$ of a liter of horchata in her refrigerator.  **How many glasses of horchata can she pour?**   glasses

hints.content: ###Modeling the situation  $\blueE{(\text{amount per glass})}\times \maroonE{\text{glasses}} = \purpleD{(\text{total amount})}$  We don't know the number of glasses. Let's rewrite the multiplication equation as an equivalent division equation. Then we can fill in the values we know and divide.

###Writing a division equation  $\begin{align} \maroonE{\text{glasses}} &= \purpleD{(\text{total amount})} \div \blueE{(\text{amount per glass})} \\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac{7}{10}} \div \blueE{\dfrac{1}{8}} \end{align}$

###Rewriting with the reciprocal  Dividing by $\blueE{\dfrac{1}{8}}$ is equivalent to multiplying by its reciprocal.  The reciprocal of $\blueE{\dfrac{1}{8}}$ is $\goldE{\dfrac{8}{1}}$.  $\begin{align} \maroonE{\text{glasses}} &= \purpleD{\dfrac{7}{10}} \div \blueE{\dfrac{1}{8}} \\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac{7}{10}} \times \goldE{\dfrac{8}{1}}\\\\ &= \maroonE{\dfrac{56}{10}}\\\\ &= \maroonE{\dfrac{28}{5}} \end{align}$
It makes sense to pour a fraction of a glass, so Ana can pour $\maroonE{5\dfrac{3}{5}}$ glasses.

question.content: Ben likes to go in the covered dome when he feels overexcited. The dome covers an area of $1\dfrac{2}{3}$ square meters, which is $\dfrac{5}{840}$ of the total area of the playground.  **What is the total area of the playground?**   square meters

hints.content: ###Modeling the situation  $\blueE{(\text{total area})}\times \maroonE{\text{comparison}} = \purpleD{(\text{dome area})}$  We don't know the total area. Let's rewrite the multiplication equation as an equivalent division equation. Then we can fill in the values we know and divide.

###Writing a division equation  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{total area})} &= \purpleD{(\text{dome area})} \div \maroonE{\text{comparison}} \\\\ &= \purpleD{1\dfrac{2}{3}} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{5}{840}} \end{align}$  It will be easier to divide if we rewrite the mixed number as a fraction greater than $1$. [[☃ explanation 1]]  $\blueE{(\text{total area})} = \purpleD{\dfrac{5}{3}} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{5}{840}}$

###Rewriting with the reciprocal  Dividing by $\maroonE{\dfrac{5}{840}}$ is equivalent to multiplying by its reciprocal.    The reciprocal of $\maroonE{\dfrac{5}{840}}$ is $\goldE{\dfrac{840}{5}}$.  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{total area})} &= \purpleD{\dfrac{5}{3}} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{5}{840}}\\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac{\cancel{5}}{3}} \times \goldE{\dfrac{840}{\cancel{5}}}\\\\ &= \blueE{\dfrac{840}{3}}\\\\ &= \blueE{280} \end{align}$  [[☃ explanation 1]]
The total area of the playground is $\blueE{280}$ square meters.

question.content: Yuki works at an aquarium. To clean a tank, she calculates $\dfrac{7}{900}$ of the tank's total volume, and she adds that much cleaning solution to the tank. For a certain tank, this works out to be $2\dfrac13\,\text{L}$ of cleaning solution.   **What is the total volume of the tank?**   liters

hints.content: ###Modeling the situation  $\blueE{(\text{total volume})}\times \maroonE{\text{comparison}} = \purpleD{(\text{solution volume})}$  We don't know the total volume. Let's rewrite the multiplication equation as an equivalent division equation. Then we can fill in the values we know and divide.

###Writing a division equation  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{total volume})} &= \purpleD{(\text{solution volume})} \div \maroonE{\text{comparison}} \\\\ &= \purpleD{2\dfrac{1}{3}} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{7}{900}} \end{align}$  It will be easier to divide if we rewrite the mixed number as a fraction greater than $1$. [[☃ explanation 1]]  $\blueE{(\text{total volume})} = \purpleD{\dfrac{7}{3}} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{7}{900}}$

###Rewriting with the reciprocal  Dividing by $\maroonE{\dfrac{7}{900}}$ is equivalent to multiplying by its reciprocal.    The reciprocal of $\maroonE{\dfrac{7}{900}}$ is $\goldE{\dfrac{900}{7}}$.  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{total volume})} &= \purpleD{\dfrac{7}{3}} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{7}{900}}\\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac{\cancel{7}}{3}} \times \goldE{\dfrac{900}{\cancel{7}}}\\\\ &= \blueE{\dfrac{900}{3}}\\\\ &= \blueE{300} \end{align}$
The total volume of the tank is $\blueE{300}$ liters.

question.content: Chidi puts $2\dfrac35\,\text{kg}$ of bird seed in his large feeder. This is $1\dfrac{3}{10}$ times as much seed as he puts in his smaller feeder.  **How much bird seed does Chidi put in his smaller feeder?**   $\text{kg}$

hints.content: ###Modeling the situation  $\blueE{(\text{small amount})}\times \maroonE{\text{comparison}} = \purpleD{(\text{large amount})}$  We don't know the amount in the small feeder. Let's rewrite the multiplication equation as an equivalent division equation. Then we can fill in the values we know and divide.

###Writing a division equation  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{small amount})} &= \purpleD{(\text{large amount})} \div \maroonE{\text{comparison}} \\\\ &= \purpleD{2\dfrac{3}{5}} \div \maroonE{1\dfrac{3}{10}} \end{align}$  It will be easier to divide if we rewrite the mixed numbers as fractions greater than $1$. [[☃ explanation 1]]  $\blueE{(\text{small amount})} = \purpleD{\dfrac{13}{5}} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{13}{10}}$

###Rewriting with the reciprocal  Dividing by $\maroonE{\dfrac{13}{10}}$ is equivalent to multiplying by its reciprocal.    The reciprocal of $\maroonE{\dfrac{13}{10}}$ is $\goldE{\dfrac{10}{13}}$.  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{small amount})} &= \purpleD{\dfrac{13}{5}} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{13}{10}}\\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac{\cancel{13}}{5}} \times \goldE{\dfrac{10}{\cancel{13}}}\\\\ &= \blueE{\dfrac{10}{5}}\\\\ &= \blueE{2} \end{align}$
Chidi puts $\blueE{2}\,\text{kg}$ of bird seed in his smaller feeder.

question.content: Avi and Micah are teammates on a track and field team. Avi's best long jump is $1\dfrac{1}{6}$ times as long as Micah's. Avi's best long jump is $3\dfrac{1}{2}$ meters.  **How long is Micah's best long jump?**   meters

hints.content: ###Modeling the situation  $\blueE{(\text{Micah's jump})}\times \maroonE{\text{comparison}} = \purpleD{(\text{Avi's jump})}$  We don't know how long Micah's best jump is. Let's rewrite the multiplication equation as an equivalent division equation. Then we can fill in the values we know and divide.

###Writing a division equation  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{Micah's jump})} &= \purpleD{(\text{Avi's jump})} \div \maroonE{\text{comparison}} \\\\ &= \purpleD{3\dfrac{1}{2}} \div \maroonE{1\dfrac{1}{6}} \end{align}$  It will be easier to divide if we rewrite the mixed numbers as fractions greater than $1$. [[☃ explanation 1]]  $\blueE{(\text{Micah's jump})} = \purpleD{\dfrac{7}{2}} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{7}{6}}$

###Rewriting with the reciprocal  Dividing by $\maroonE{\dfrac{7}{6}}$ is equivalent to multiplying by its reciprocal.    The reciprocal of $\maroonE{\dfrac{7}{6}}$ is $\goldE{\dfrac{6}{7}}$.  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{Micah's jump})} &= \purpleD{\dfrac{7}{2}} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{7}{6}}\\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac{\cancel{7}}{2}} \times \goldE{\dfrac{6}{\cancel{7}}}\\\\ &= \blueE{\dfrac{6}{2}}\\\\ &= \blueE{3} \end{align}$
Micah's best long jump is $\blueE{3}$ meters.

question.content: Rex and Samir participated in a . Rex walked for $1\dfrac23$ hours, and Samir walked for $3\dfrac13$ hours.  **Complete the comparison.**  Samir walked  times as many hours as Rex walked.

hints.content: ###Modeling the situation  $\blueE{(\text{Rex's hours})}\times \maroonE{\text{comparison}} = \purpleD{(\text{Samir's hours})}$  We don't know the comparison. Let's rewrite the multiplication equation as an equivalent division equation. Then we can fill in the values we know and divide.

###Writing a division equation  $\begin{align} \maroonE{\text{comparison}} &= \purpleD{(\text{Samir's hours})} \div \blueE{(\text{Rex's hours})} \\\\ &= \purpleD{3\dfrac{1}{3}} \div \blueE{1\dfrac{2}{3}} \end{align}$  It will be easier to divide if we rewrite the mixed numbers as fractions greater than $1$. [[☃ explanation 1]]  $\maroonE{\text{comparison}} = \purpleD{\dfrac{10}{3}} \div \blueE{\dfrac{5}{3}}$

###Rewriting with the reciprocal  Dividing by $\blueE{\dfrac{5}{3}}$ is equivalent to multiplying by its reciprocal.    The reciprocal of $\blueE{\dfrac{5}{3}}$ is $\goldE{\dfrac{3}{5}}$.  $\begin{align} \maroonE{\text{comparison}} &= \purpleD{\dfrac{10}{3}} \div \blueE{\dfrac{5}{3}}\\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac{10}{\cancel{3}}} \times \goldE{\dfrac{\cancel{3}}{5}}\\\\ &= \maroonE{\dfrac{10}{5}}\\\\ &= \maroonE{2} \end{align}$
Samir walked $2$ times as many hours as Rex walked.

question.content: Ayana is $1\dfrac12$ meters tall. Her little sister Chike is $1\dfrac14$ meters tall.  **Complete the comparison.**  Ayana is  times as tall as Chike.

hints.content: ###Modeling the situation  $\blueE{(\text{Chike's height})}\times \maroonE{\text{comparison}} = \purpleD{(\text{Ayana's height})}$  We don't know the comparison. Let's rewrite the multiplication equation as an equivalent division equation. Then we can fill in the values we know and divide.

###Writing a division equation  $\begin{align} \maroonE{\text{comparison}} &= \purpleD{(\text{Ayana's height})} \div \blueE{(\text{Chike's height})} \\\\ &= \purpleD{1\dfrac{1}{2}} \div \blueE{1\dfrac{1}{4}} \end{align}$  It will be easier to divide if we rewrite the mixed numbers as fractions greater than $1$. [[☃ explanation 1]]  $\maroonE{\text{comparison}} = \purpleD{\dfrac{3}{2}} \div \blueE{\dfrac{5}{4}}$

###Rewriting with the reciprocal  Dividing by $\blueE{\dfrac{5}{4}}$ is equivalent to multiplying by its reciprocal.    The reciprocal of $\blueE{\dfrac{5}{4}}$ is $\goldE{\dfrac{4}{5}}$.  $\begin{align} \maroonE{\text{comparison}} &= \purpleD{\dfrac{3}{2}} \div \blueE{\dfrac{5}{4}}\\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac{3}{2}} \times \goldE{\dfrac{4}{5}}\\\\ &= \maroonE{\dfrac{12}{10}}\\\\ &= \maroonE{\dfrac{6}{5}} \end{align}$
Ayana is $\dfrac{6}{5}$ times as tall as Chike.

question.content: A pygmy hippo and a regular hippo were recently born. The pygmy hippo had a mass of $5\dfrac{1}{2}\,\text{kg}$ at birth. The regular hippo had a mass of $24\dfrac{1}{2}\,\text{kg}$ at birth.  **Complete the comparison.**  At birth, the regular hippo massed  times as much as the pygmy hippo.

hints.content: ###Modeling the situation  $\blueE{(\text{pygmy hippo mass})}\times \maroonE{\text{comparison}} = \purpleD{(\text{regular hippo mass})}$  We don't know the comparison. Let's rewrite the multiplication equation as an equivalent division equation. Then we can fill in the values we know and divide.

###Writing a division equation  $\begin{align} \maroonE{\text{comparison}} &= \purpleD{(\text{regular hippo mass})} \div \blueE{(\text{pygmy hippo mass})} \\\\ &= \purpleD{24\dfrac{1}{2}} \div \blueE{5\dfrac{1}{2}} \end{align}$  It will be easier to divide if we rewrite the mixed numbers as fractions greater than $1$. [[☃ explanation 1]]  $\maroonE{\text{comparison}} = \purpleD{\dfrac{49}{2}} \div \blueE{\dfrac{11}{2}}$

###Rewriting with the reciprocal  Dividing by $\blueE{\dfrac{11}{2}}$ is equivalent to multiplying by its reciprocal.    The reciprocal of $\blueE{\dfrac{11}{2}}$ is $\goldE{\dfrac{2}{11}}$.  $\begin{align} \maroonE{\text{comparison}} &= \purpleD{\dfrac{49}{2}} \div \blueE{\dfrac{11}{2}}\\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac{49}{\cancel{2}}} \times \goldE{\dfrac{\cancel{2}}{11}}\\\\ &= \maroonE{\dfrac{49}{11}} \end{align}$
At birth, the regular hippo massed $4\dfrac{5}{11}$ times as much as the pygmy hippo.

question.content: Some friends are planning to make a neighborhood garden. The total area available for the garden is $210$ square meters, and they want this to be $1\dfrac{1}{3}$ times the area of the  in the garden.   **What should the area of the plant beds be?**   square meters

hints.content: ###Modeling the situation  $\blueE{(\text{plant bed area})}\times \maroonE{\text{comparison}} = \purpleD{(\text{total area})}$  We don't know the area of the plant beds. Let's rewrite the multiplication equation as an equivalent division equation. Then we can fill in the values we know and divide.

###Writing a division equation  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{plant bed area})} &= \purpleD{(\text{total area})} \div \maroonE{\text{comparison}} \\\\ &= \purpleD{210} \div \maroonE{1\dfrac{1}{3}} \end{align}$  It will be easier to divide if we rewrite the mixed number as a fraction greater than $1$. [[☃ explanation 1]]  $\blueE{(\text{plant bed area})} = \purpleD{210} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{4}{3}}$

###Rewriting with the reciprocal  Dividing by $\maroonE{\dfrac{4}{3}}$ is equivalent to multiplying by its reciprocal.    The reciprocal of $\maroonE{\dfrac{4}{3}}$ is $\goldE{\dfrac{3}{4}}$.  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{plant bed area})} &= \purpleD{210} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{4}{3}}\\\\ &= \purpleD{210} \times \goldE{\dfrac{3}{4}}\\\\ &= \blueE{\dfrac{630}{4}}\\\\ &= \blueE{\dfrac{315}{2}} \end{align}$
The area of the plant beds should be $\blueE{157\dfrac12}$ square meters.

question.content: Bjorn is making , and he does not have enough of all the ingredients. He decides to make $\dfrac56$ of a whole recipe, which means he uses $1\dfrac14\,\text{L}$ of water.   **How much water is in a whole recipe?**   $\text{L}$

hints.content: ###Modeling the situation  $\blueE{(\text{whole recipe})}\times \maroonE{\text{comparison}} = \purpleD{(\text{scaled down})}$  We don't know the amount of water in a whole recipe. Let's rewrite the multiplication equation as an equivalent division equation. Then we can fill in the values we know and divide.

###Writing a division equation  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{whole recipe})} &= \purpleD{(\text{scaled down})} \div \maroonE{\text{comparison}} \\\\ &= \purpleD{1\dfrac14} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{5}{6}} \end{align}$  It will be easier to divide if we rewrite the mixed number as a fraction greater than $1$. [[☃ explanation 1]]  $\blueE{(\text{whole recipe})} = \purpleD{\dfrac54} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{5}{6}}$

###Rewriting with the reciprocal  Dividing by $\maroonE{\dfrac{5}{6}}$ is equivalent to multiplying by its reciprocal.    The reciprocal of $\maroonE{\dfrac{5}{6}}$ is $\goldE{\dfrac{6}{5}}$.  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{whole recipe})} &= \purpleD{\dfrac54} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{5}{6}}\\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac{\cancel5}{4}} \times \goldE{\dfrac{6}{\cancel5}}\\\\ &= \blueE{\dfrac{6}{4}}\\\\ &= \blueE{\dfrac{3}{2}} \end{align}$
A whole recipe has $\blueE{\dfrac32}\,\text{L}$ of water.

question.content: After it snows, it takes Maria and her little sister Anita $\dfrac12$ of an hour to shovel the snow off of the sidewalks on their street. This is $\dfrac{2}{3}$ of the time it takes Maria to do the same job by herself.  **How long does it take Maria do this job by herself?**   hours

hints.content: ###Modeling the situation  $\blueE{(\text{time for Maria})}\times \maroonE{\text{comparison}} = \purpleD{(\text{time for the pair})}$  We don't know how much time it takes just Maria to do this job. Let's rewrite the multiplication equation as an equivalent division equation. Then we can fill in the values we know and divide.

###Writing a division equation  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{time for Maria})} &= \purpleD{(\text{time for the pair})} \div \maroonE{\text{comparison}} \\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac{1}{2}} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{2}{3}} \end{align}$

###Rewriting with the reciprocal  Dividing by $\maroonE{\dfrac{2}{3}}$ is equivalent to multiplying by its reciprocal.    The reciprocal of $\maroonE{\dfrac{2}{3}}$ is $\goldE{\dfrac{3}{2}}$.  $\begin{align} \blueE{(\text{time for Maria})} &= \purpleD{\dfrac{1}{2}} \div \maroonE{\dfrac{2}{3}}\\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac{1}{2}} \times \goldE{\dfrac{3}{2}}\\\\ &= \blueE{\dfrac{3}{4}} \end{align}$
It takes Maria $\blueE{\dfrac{3}{4}}$ of an hour to do this job by herself.
